articles.headline: Shepard Smith, Fox News Anchor, Abruptly Departs From Network
articles.snippet: The chief news anchor at Fox News, who stood apart from the network’s commentators, announced his departure at the close of his regular broadcast.
articles.abstract: The chief news anchor at Fox News, who stood apart from the network’s commentators, announced his departure at the close of his regular broadcast.
articles.lead_paragraph: To critics who accuse Fox News of being uniformly pro-Trump, the network often points to the blunt-truth reporting of Shepard Smith, its veteran chief news anchor, whose coverage of the Trump White House stood out on a channel known best for conservative opinion.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: Facebook’s Libra Cryptocurrency Faces Exodus of Partners
articles.snippet: Stripe, Mastercard, Visa and eBay said they were dropping out of the effort, a week after PayPal pulled out.
articles.abstract: Stripe, Mastercard, Visa and eBay said they were dropping out of the effort, a week after PayPal pulled out.
articles.lead_paragraph: Facebook’s troubled cryptocurrency initiative, Libra, suffered new blows on Friday as the departures of key partners became an exodus.
articles.byline: By Erin Griffith and Nathaniel Popper

articles.headline: China’s Political Correctness: One Country, No Arguments
articles.snippet: The Communist Party has spent decades preparing the people to defend a united homeland. Hong Kong’s protests show it has paid off.
articles.abstract: The Communist Party has spent decades preparing the people to defend a united homeland. Hong Kong’s protests show it has paid off.
articles.lead_paragraph: Hong Kong’s protests have disrupted Yang Yang’s family life. Though the 29-year-old lives in mainland China, he was inspired by the demonstrations to write a song about freedom and upload it to the internet. When censors deleted it, he complained to his family.
articles.byline: By Li Yuan

articles.headline: Those Foreign Business Ties? The Trump Sons Have Plenty Too
articles.snippet: The Trumps have criticized Hunter Biden for doing business overseas while his father was vice president. Last month, the Trumps won approval in Scotland to build 500 homes.
articles.abstract: The Trumps have criticized Hunter Biden for doing business overseas while his father was vice president. Last month, the Trumps won approval in Scotland to build 500 homes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last month, the Trump family business received approval from a local government in Scotland for a major expansion of its golf resort near Aberdeen, marking the largest real estate development financed by the Trump Organization since the 2016 election.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton, Steve Eder and Ben Protess

articles.headline: Giuliani Is Said to Be Under Investigation for Ukraine Work
articles.snippet: Prosecutors are investigating whether the president’s lawyer broke laws meant to prevent covert foreign influence on the government.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors are investigating whether the president’s lawyer broke laws meant to prevent covert foreign influence on the government.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Federal prosecutors in Manhattan are investigating whether President Trump’s personal lawyer Rudolph W. Giuliani broke lobbying laws in his dealings in Ukraine, according to two people familiar with the inquiry.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt, Ben Protess, Kenneth P. Vogel and William K. Rashbaum

articles.headline: James Comey Would Like to Help
articles.snippet: The former F.B.I. director wants an end to the Trump presidency. And yes, he knows you might think he caused it.
articles.abstract: The former F.B.I. director wants an end to the Trump presidency. And yes, he knows you might think he caused it.
articles.lead_paragraph: James Comey slumps strategically in restaurants — all 6-foot-8 of him, drooping faux-furtively with his back to the room — and daydreams about deleting the civic-minded Twitter feed where a bipartisan coalition pronounces him a national disgrace.
articles.byline: By Matt Flegenheimer

articles.headline: Impeachment Support Grows, but So Does the Public Divide
articles.snippet: Americans are as divided over impeachment as they are over President Trump. But support for the Democrats’ inquiry is building even in places Mr. Trump won, and among politically crucial independents.
articles.abstract: Americans are as divided over impeachment as they are over President Trump. But support for the Democrats’ inquiry is building even in places Mr. Trump won, and among politically crucial independents.
articles.lead_paragraph: CULPEPER, Va. — Over lunch at the Frost Cafe, a corner diner in a picturesque pocket of Virginia that President Trump won handily in 2016, opinion over his impeachment is as varied as anywhere in the country.
articles.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg

articles.headline: ‘This Did Not Go Well’: Inside PG&E’s Blackout Control Room
articles.snippet: As the utility turned off power to millions of Californians, its website went down and it struggled to communicate with local officials and inform residents.
articles.abstract: As the utility turned off power to millions of Californians, its website went down and it struggled to communicate with local officials and inform residents.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It was a problem that California had come to dread. Weather models were signaling extreme winds and dry conditions from one end of the state to the other. The risk of wildfires was high.
articles.byline: By Ivan Penn

articles.headline: Bill Gates Met With Jeffrey Epstein Many Times, Despite His Past
articles.snippet: Mr. Gates has minimized his ties to Mr. Epstein. But a Times investigation reveals they had a closer relationship than previously known.
articles.abstract: Mr. Gates has minimized his ties to Mr. Epstein. But a Times investigation reveals they had a closer relationship than previously known.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jeffrey Epstein, the convicted sex offender who committed suicide in prison, managed to lure an astonishing array of rich, powerful and famous men into his orbit.
articles.byline: By Emily Flitter and James B. Stewart

articles.headline: Trump’s Abrupt Shifts in Middle East Unnerve U.S. Allies
articles.snippet: President Trump’s acquiescence to a Turkish raid on the Kurds in northern Syria alarmed allies for its unpredictability as much as its betrayal.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s acquiescence to a Turkish raid on the Kurds in northern Syria alarmed allies for its unpredictability as much as its betrayal.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump’s surprise acquiescence to a Turkish incursion into northern Syria this week has shaken American allies, and not just because it was a betrayal of a loyal partner. What alarmed them even more was his sheer unpredictability.
articles.byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick, Ben Hubbard and David M. Halbfinger

articles.headline: How ‘White Guilt’ in the Age of Trump Shapes the Democratic Primary
articles.snippet: The changing racial attitudes of white liberals are changing how 2020 candidates try to win votes.
articles.abstract: The changing racial attitudes of white liberals are changing how 2020 candidates try to win votes.
articles.lead_paragraph: ANKENY, Iowa — When Donald Trump was elected, John Olsen felt enraged by the racial tension that fueled his rise, the silence of his white neighbors and the stories of racial discrimination he heard from his nonwhite friends.
articles.byline: By Astead W. Herndon

articles.headline: Abandoned by U.S. in Syria, Kurds Find New Ally in American Foe
articles.snippet: Under fire by Turkish forces, the militia that battled ISIS threw in its lot with Syria’s Russian-backed government.
articles.abstract: Under fire by Turkish forces, the militia that battled ISIS threw in its lot with Syria’s Russian-backed government.
articles.lead_paragraph: DOHUK, Iraq — Kurdish forces long allied with the United States in Syria announced a new deal on Sunday with the government in Damascus, a sworn enemy of Washington that is backed by Russia, as Turkish troops moved deeper into their territory and President Trump ordered the withdrawal of the American military from northern Syria.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard, Charlie Savage, Eric Schmitt and Patrick Kingsley

articles.headline: Pullback Leaves Green Berets Feeling ‘Ashamed,’ and Kurdish Allies Describing ‘Betrayal’
articles.snippet: As Turkish forces cross into Kurdish areas of northern Syria, the orders from Washington to U.S. troops are simple: Stand back. Let the Kurds fight for themselves.
articles.abstract: As Turkish forces cross into Kurdish areas of northern Syria, the orders from Washington to U.S. troops are simple: Stand back. Let the Kurds fight for themselves.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — American commandos were working alongside Kurdish forces at an outpost in eastern Syria last year when they were attacked by columns of Syrian government tanks and hundreds of troops, including Russian mercenaries. In the next hours, the Americans threw the Pentagon’s arsenal at them, including B-52 strategic bombers. The attack was stopped.
articles.byline: By Eric Schmitt, Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Ben Hubbard and Helene Cooper

articles.headline: With No End to Unrest in Sight, Hong Kong’s Economic Pain Deepens
articles.snippet: An unmistakable sense of alarm is spreading among both small business owners and corporate executives who see no way out of the impasse.
articles.abstract: An unmistakable sense of alarm is spreading among both small business owners and corporate executives who see no way out of the impasse.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — It was the second day of Golden Week, usually one of Hong Kong’s busiest shopping periods, and Matthew Tam and his co-workers at a jewelry store were looking as lonely as a band of Maytag repairmen, surrounded by display cases of luxury watches with nary a customer in sight.
articles.byline: By Andrew Jacobs

articles.headline: Inside Boeing, a C.E.O. Stripped of Power and a Top Executive Under Fire
articles.snippet: The decision to strip Dennis Muilenburg of his chairman title culminated months of internal debate over whether to hold top executives accountable after the 737 Max crashes.
articles.abstract: The decision to strip Dennis Muilenburg of his chairman title culminated months of internal debate over whether to hold top executives accountable after the 737 Max crashes.
articles.lead_paragraph: Early Friday morning, Boeing’s board gathered on a conference call that had been hastily arranged the day before. Dennis A. Muilenburg, the company’s chief executive and the chairman of the board, was not invited.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and David Gelles

articles.headline: American Basketball vs. Chinese Hardball: Guess Who Won
articles.snippet: The N.B.A. is the latest entertainment giant to incite nationalist anger in China, where political submission has become the price of admission to a market of 1.4 billion.
articles.abstract: The N.B.A. is the latest entertainment giant to incite nationalist anger in China, where political submission has become the price of admission to a market of 1.4 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Back in the Cold War, the sclerotic Soviet system proved no match for the lure of American soft power: bluejeans, jazz, rock ’n’ roll, Coca-Cola, Hollywood. All became symbols of American freedom and prosperity that no amount of communist prohibitions could stop.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Chris Buckley

articles.headline: The Should-Be Solution to the Student-Debt Problem
articles.snippet: Income-driven repayment programs cover eight million borrowers, but they could be helping more if they were simpler and reached the people who needed them.
articles.abstract: Income-driven repayment programs cover eight million borrowers, but they could be helping more if they were simpler and reached the people who needed them.
articles.lead_paragraph: With more than 7.5 million student loan borrowers in default and nearly 2 million others seriously behind on their payments, there’s little question that the handful of federal programs designed to help struggling borrowers pay what they can afford aren’t working for everyone.
articles.byline: By Tara Siegel Bernard

articles.headline: Fox News Is Trump’s Chief TV Booster. So Why Is He Griping About It?
articles.snippet: A phone call from the president to the Fox News chief executive suggests a crack in the alliance between him and his favorite news network.
articles.abstract: A phone call from the president to the Fox News chief executive suggests a crack in the alliance between him and his favorite news network.
articles.lead_paragraph: Fed up with the coverage on his favorite cable news station, President Trump decided late this summer that a direct intervention was needed. So he telephoned the chief executive of Fox News, Suzanne Scott, and let loose.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Nobel Economics Prize Goes to Pioneers in Reducing Poverty
articles.snippet: Three professors, Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo, both of M.I.T., and Michael Kremer of Harvard, were honored.
articles.abstract: Three professors, Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo, both of M.I.T., and Michael Kremer of Harvard, were honored.
articles.lead_paragraph: Abhijit Banerjee and Esther Duflo of M.I.T. and Michael Kremer of Harvard have devoted more than 20 years of economic research to developing new ways to study — and help — the world’s poor.
articles.byline: By Jeanna Smialek

articles.headline: Bolton Objected to Ukraine Pressure Campaign, Calling Giuliani ‘a Hand Grenade’
articles.snippet: John R. Bolton, then the national security adviser, ordered an aide to report the machinations by the president’s personal attorney to a White House lawyer, House investigators were told.
articles.abstract: John R. Bolton, then the national security adviser, ordered an aide to report the machinations by the president’s personal attorney to a White House lawyer, House investigators were told.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The effort to pressure Ukraine for political help provoked a heated confrontation inside the White House last summer that so alarmed John R. Bolton, then the national security adviser, that he told an aide to alert White House lawyers, House investigators were told on Monday.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: Trump Followed His Gut on Syria. Calamity Came Fast.
articles.snippet: All the warnings were there. But President Trump’s reliance on his instincts, and his relationships, led him to ignore the consequences of a move that has emboldened Russia, Iran and the Islamic State.
articles.abstract: All the warnings were there. But President Trump’s reliance on his instincts, and his relationships, led him to ignore the consequences of a move that has emboldened Russia, Iran and the Islamic State.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump’s acquiescence to Turkey’s move to send troops deep inside Syrian territory has in only one week’s time turned into a bloody carnage, forced the abandonment of a successful five-year-long American project to keep the peace on a volatile border, and given an unanticipated victory to four American adversaries: Russia, Iran, the Syrian government and the Islamic State.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Violent Video Was Product of Right-Wing Provocateurs and Trump Allies
articles.snippet: The clip underscores how the president’s escalating war on what he calls the “fake news” media has encouraged media-savvy members of the far-right fringe to defend Mr. Trump with extreme language and images.
articles.abstract: The clip underscores how the president’s escalating war on what he calls the “fake news” media has encouraged media-savvy members of the far-right fringe to defend Mr. Trump with extreme language and images.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The creator of a gruesome video that showed a fake President Trump killing journalists and political opponents and that was played at a meeting of a pro-Trump group over the weekend  is part of a loose network of right-wing provocateurs with a direct line to the White House.
articles.byline: By Annie Karni, Kevin Roose and Katie Rogers
